bibl.title: Moy Chong v.
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

div1.p: IN THE CIRCUIT COURT OF THE UNITED STATES, FOR THE DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON, Northern Western DIVISION.
In the Matter of the Application of Moy Chong for a Writ of Habeas Corpus.
Comes now the above named Moy Chong and for his petition and complaint in writing for a Writ of Habeas Corpus, on oath res- pectfully shows to this court.

That on or about the 10th day of March, A.D., 1892, he left the city of Portland, Oregon, where he had resided for eleven years immediately prior to said time, and had been for six years last past engaged in the merchantile business, for Hong Kong, Chi- na, and that he did, prior to taking hissaid departure, appear before one J. E. Marks, a Notary Public andthen and there sub- scribed and make the certificate hereunto attached a copy marked as exhibit "A" and making and forming a part of this petition.

2. That all the facts and circumstances as set forth in said statement are true; that petitioner had, for six years last past been actively engaged as a Chinese merchant in Portland, Oregon, and was at said time doing business at 140 Second Street and was a member of the firm of On Chong Wa & Co., and as a member of said firm still having and retaining all of his said interests in said business, which was the sum of $2,000 and still having and re- taining and receiving his share of the profits from said business and was at said time a bone fide owner and holder of a one-seventh interest in said business, the capital stock of said business be- ing $14,000 and your petitioner being one of the partners in said business; and your petitioner fully and completely relied upon said J. E. Marks as an attorney at law for the proper wording and making of said certificate and fully believes that the same fully

completely complies with the law as in such cases made and provided; that to said certificate is attached a photograph of your petitioner, which photograph petitioner had taken for the purpose of having same attached to said certificate; and petition- er further states that at said time he did obtain the statement of persons well and favorable known to him, one of said persons be- ing J. D. Wisdom and one W. W. Taylor who are bote well and per- sonally acquainted with the petitioner and who are now absent from the city's of Portland; and that thereafter on the 4th day of May 1893, said W. W. Taylor did make oath that he was the identical W. W. Taylor who made the foregoing statement and your petitioner did on the same day obtain an affidavit from one Lee Chung his partner in said business, which affidavits of said Taylore and said Lee Chung were attached to said petition and were duly pre- sente d to the collector of customs at Tacoma, Washington.

You petitioner further states that he did, on or about the 10th day of March, 1892, take his departure from Portland for Hong Kong, China, and did there remain and visit relatives and friends and transact his business and the business of said firm, which was that of viewing, examining and ascertaining the prices of goods and making arrangements for the buying and shipping from the manufacturer in China; that thereafter, he did, about the 10th day of January, 1893, take passage on the steamship Vic- toria at Hong Kong, China, to return to the United States of America, and that he did pay his fare for said passage and did re- turn to and was landed at the steamboat wharf at Tacoma, and did then and there present his certificate andrequest to be landed; that one Plummer, representing himself to be a deputy collector did, without any cause, right or authority, and without explain-

ing or making known to this petitioner any of his reasons for not allowing him to land, refuse to allow your petitioner to land, al- though your petitioner had in all ways and manner complied with the laws of the United States of America, and did offer and was willing to produce the witnesses who signed said statement to said certificate, together with other witnesses both white and Chinese who knew and would identify him your petitioner as having resided in the city of Portland for a number of years last past, and as being a good, honest, upright and bona fide merchant in said city and a member of the firm doing business at 140 Second street, in the city of Portland, Oregon, but regardless of said of- fers, said Plummer made to your petitioner or to one Moy Yuck who well understands and speaks the English language, no satisfactory explanation whatsoever, and gave him no reason whatsoever for re- fusing to admit your petitioner, but did take from your petitioner his certificate with his photograph hereto attached, and the statement as thereto attached signed by the petitioner and re- spective parties as set forth in exhibit "A", and did refuse to re- turn same to your petitioner and has ever since said tine retained same and does still continue to retain same, and your petitioner has not had or seen the same since said time, and the same is still had and retained by said Plummer or the Collector of Customs or some one under him, without the consent and against the wish and protest of petitioner, and petitioner further states that on the evening of the 8th day of May, 1893 about the hour opf 5 o'clock, he was informed that the said steamer Victoria, with a large num- ber of Chinese passengers, about two hundred in number, nearly all of whom were strangers to this petitioner, and of whom he knew nothing, and had no relation, would, at 4 o'clock on the morning of the 9th inst. loose from the wharf at Tacoma, and be cleared

for and return upon her return trip to Hong Kong; and that your petitioner, together with his two companions, who are likewise merchants and who likewise ask for a writ of abeas corpus, would be forcibly, unjustly, unlawfully and illegally, and without any cause whatsoever, and without being informed as to any cause, com- pelled to remain upon said vessel and thus be compelled to return to Hong Kong. That your petitioner did cause to be made, diligent search and inquiry to find and ascertain the whereabouts of this Honorable Court to apply to it for a writ of habeas corpus, and did apply in absence of the Court to the Commissioner of your Honorable Court for said writ, which was refused by said Commissioner for the reason that he had no authority to issue said writ, and that your petitioner was then compelled to resort to and did apply to the Superior Court of Pierce County, washington, for a writ of habeas corpus, setting forth the facts and circumstances, which application was consider- ed by the Court and by said Court, the Honorable W. H. Pritchard who granted, said writ in the words following to-wit: "Let the writ of habeas corpus and the warrant issue as prayed for in the within complaint and petition. May 8, 1893. W. H. Pritchard, Judge." That the said W. H. Pritchard was, at that time one of the duly elected and qualified and acting jusges of the Superior Court of the State of Washington, for the County of Pierce, said cause being number 9689 as appears by the record and files of said Superior Court of the State of Washington, for the county of Pierce; and that thereupon the clerk of said court did, under the seal of said court, issue said writ of habeas corpus and warrant fo for the arrest of said Wah Ni Moy Chung as prayed for in said petition, and under said writ the sheriff did proceed to the steamboat wharf and to the steamer Victoria, and ask for the said Wah Ni Moy Chung, who was called for by the captain of said steamer, and without any fur- ther orders and without any protest, ordered the said Moy Chung to go ashore, which said Moy Chung then and thereupon do, without any protest or resistance or proceedings of any kind of any rep-

resentative whatsoever of the United States of America; and that the said captain did thereafter appear before the said Superior Court and make and file his written answer to said writ of habeas corpus, and that then and thereupon, and upon the filing of said answer, the said petitionre Wah Ni Moy Chong by his counsel demurred there to, which demurrer was by the court sistained andafter hearing the respective counsel and arguments of same, the said Wah Moy Chung was then and thereupon by said court, in the presence of the oficers of the government discharged by the said Superior Court which he was be- fore, all of which proceedings, including the said petition, or- der of said court, writ of habeas corpus, warrant of arrest and return of the officers upon it andsaid process, answer of the said captain, the ruling and order of the court and record of the pro- ceedings of the respective parties, appears of record in the rec- ords of the Superior Court of the State of Washington for the County of Pierce in cause number 9689 as given, made and filed therein.

That immediately upon the discharge of said Moy Chung as afore- said he was then and thereupon arrested charged with being ille- gally in the United States of America, and was taken before Honor- able Miles E. Clifford, Court Commissioner of theCircuit Court of the United States at Tacoma, who proceeded to inquire into said cause, and did refuse to allow said petitioner to be returned over to the United States marshall to be returned to said steamer Vic- toria, which was still at the wharf of Tacoma and ordered that said petitioner be held and returned by the United States marshall for a hearing before him, which hearing was fixed for the 17th day of May, 1893 at 10 o'clock in the forenoon, at which hearing evi- dence was introduced for the respective parties and your said petitioner was by said Commissioner ordered discharged from which or- der, judgment and ruling, with the consent of the United States attorneys waiving all forms and regularities of giving notice, an

appeal was taken to this Honorable Court, and upon the question of jurisdiction of the United States Commissioner being, by the United States Attorney raised, this Honorable Court did, on the 5th day of June, 1893, order that your petitioner be turned over to and placed in custody of the United States marshall, J. C. Drake, who proceeded and took your said petitioner into possession and now forcibly, knowingly, unlawfully andwithout just cause is now holding, detaining and retaining and keeping in confinement your said petitioner, although he has demanded his liberty and your peti- tioner states that he can, if allowed a hearing before this Hon- orable Court, show that he has fully and completely complied with all the laws of the United States and the rules andregulations thereof, and regardless of said compliance, the collector of Cus- toms did wilfully, knowingly, arbitrarily, unjustly and unlawfully, and without any cause, right or authority, refuse to admit your said petitioner and allow him to land, and that your said peti- tioner is rightfully and justly entitled to land and be and re- main in the United States of America, and go his way to his former residence as heretofore stated and resume his business at the city of Portland, Oregon.

Your petitioner further states that he at this time is im- prisoned at the United States penitentiary at McNeil's Island, in Pierce County, Washington, and withing the jurisdiction of this court; that he is not detained by virtue of any order or process issued by the United States Court, nor by virtue ofany execution or any other process, judgment, decree or final order of any state court or any other court other then herein stated as aforesaid; and that he is not held for the violation of any law, rule or regulation or in punishment for any crime by him committed.

Petitioner further states that he is advised by Marshall K. Snell, his counsel, who resides at Tacoma, Pierce County, Washing- ton, and who is a counsellor of this court, having and holding a certificate authorizing him to practice in and before this court, that such imprisonment is illegal for the reason and facts as herein set forth, and that under and by virtue of the laws of the United States, a writ of habeas corpus directed to the said United States marshal should be issued by this honorable court to bring before it your petitioner.

WHEREFORE, your petitioner ever prays and hereby applies for a Writ of Habeas Corpus for the purpose of an inquiry into the cause of such imprisonment and restraint, and delivering him therefrom and discharging him from custody.
Dated this 6th day of June, 1893
Moy Chong (Chinese Signature)
Petitioner.
OF THE UNITED STATES, FOR THE DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON, WESTERN DIVISION
In the Matter of the Application of for a Writ of Habeas Corpus.
Moy Chong being first duly sworn on his oath deposes and says:-

That I am the petitioner named in the foregoing petition; that I have heard the same read and interpreted to me and know the contents thereof; that all matters therein stated other than the proceedings in court as therein recited, are to my personal knowledge true, and as to those matters I verily believe them to be be true, which matters referred to as stated upon information and belief, are the proceedings in court had and referred to in said petition.
Moy Chong (Chinese Signature)
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 6th day of June, 1893
Charles A Murray
Notary Public in and for Pierce County, Residing at Tacoma, Washington.
State of Washington, County of Multnomah.
:ss
Exhibit A

I, Moy Chung, being first duly sworn, say I am a resi- dent of the city of Portland, State of Oregon, andam a member of the firm of Won Chem Wo, Chinese merchants doing business at #140 n 2nd street, in said city of Portland, and that my photography is hereto attached, and stamped with a Notary Seal of the officer before whom this affidavit is made, and that I am about to depart from the United States on business connected with said firm, nd make this affidavit to enable me to identify myself on my return
(Sng) in Chinese)
(Notarial Seal of J. E. Marks)
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 10th day of March, A. D., 1892
(Sgd) J. E. Marks, Notary Public for Oregon.
(Photograph)
(Notarial Seal of J. E. Marks)

This certifies that I am per- sonally acquainted with Moye Chung, whose photograph is hereto attached and stamped with a Notary Seal of the City of Portland, State of Oregon, and know him to be a resi- dent of Portland, and to be a member of the firm of Won Chem Wo, Chinese merchants doing business at $140 2nd street in said city of Portland and that this certifivate is made to enable him to re- enter the United States should he desire to return.
Dates this 10th day of March/ A.D., 1892, at the City of Portland, State of Oregon.
Signature
J. D. Wisdom.
W. W. Taylor.
State of Oregon, County of Multnomah.
:ss.
I, W. W. Taylor, being first duly sworn, say that cer- tificate No. 3181 (in blue) dated the 10th day of March, 1892 with my signature, was signed by me.
(sgd) W. W. Taylor.
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 4th day of May, 1893.
(Sgd) J. E. Marks, Notary Public for Oregon.
(Notarial Seal of J. E. Marks)
State of Oregon, County of Multnomah
:ss.

I, Lee Chung, being first duly sworn say, that I am a mn member of the firm of Won Chem Wo, and that I have a partner by the name of Moye Chung, and the said partner left Portland about the first of April, 1892, and the photograph annexed to certifi- cate No. 3181 (in blue) dated the 10th day of March, 1892, is a good likeness of the said Moy Chung, my partner.
(Sng) Lee. Chung.
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 4th day of May, 1893
(Sgd) J. E. Marks,
Notary Public for Oregon.
(Notarial Seal of J. E. Marks)
